question: In the context of I/O management, what is spooling?
choices: Storing data temporarily while it is being transferred (buffering)
The overlapping of output of one job with input of other jobs
Storing parts of data in faster storage for performance (caching)
Hiding the peculiarities of hardware devices from the user

question: What is a key feature of a Peer-to-Peer (P2P) network?
choices: It distinguishes between clients and servers
A central lookup service is always required
All nodes are considered peers
It is primarily used for high-performance computing

question: A doubly linked list is different from a singly linked list because:
choices: It can be traversed in only one direction
Each node contains a pointer to the previous node as well as the next node
It connects the last element back to the first
It can only store two pieces of data

question: What is the fundamental principle of caching?
choices: Copying information into a faster storage system temporarily
Moving data permanently from a slow device to a faster one
Ensuring all CPUs have different data in their cache for efficiency
Using only nonvolatile memory for temporary storage

question: In a modern computer system, how do the CPU and device controllers execute?
choices: Sequentially, where the CPU must wait for every device to finish
Concurrently, competing for memory cycles
Independently, with no access to shared memory
The CPU controls all devices directly without the need for controllers

question: Providing a software stack ready for application use over the internet (e.g., a database server) is an example of:
choices: Software as a Service (SaaS)
Platform as a Service (PaaS)
Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS)
Public Cloud

question: An OS must provide mechanisms for process synchronization and communication to handle:
choices: Concurrency
Virtualization
Storage allocation
System startup

question: What is a key benefit of the open-source movement for students of operating systems?
choices: It makes operating systems more available and affordable
It prevents students from modifying the OS code
It allows students to study operating systems by examining the source code itself
It has led to fewer operating systems being available

question: In Operating Systems, memory management is responsible for:
choices: Keeping track of which parts of memory are being used and by whom
Mapping files onto secondary storage
Providing mechanisms for deadlock handling
Scheduling disk access for optimal performance

question: In virtualization, when is emulation typically used?
choices: When the guest OS is natively compiled for the same CPU as the host
When the source CPU type is different from the target CPU type
When running applications within data centers
When the Virtual Machine Manager (VMM) runs natively on the hardware

question: What is the function of the system timer?
choices: To keep track of the time of day for the user
To measure the speed of I/O devices
To prevent a process from getting stuck in an infinite loop
To trigger the bootstrap program on startup

question: Which of the following is NOT an activity of process management?
choices: Creating and deleting user and system processes
Deciding which processes to move into and out of memory
Providing mechanisms for process synchronization
Suspending and resuming processes

question: A system where a server responds to requests generated by clients is known as:
choices: Peer-to-Peer computing
Client-Server computing
Traditional computing
Real-time embedded computing

question: Mobile computing environments like iOS and Android differ from traditional laptops by offering:
choices: Less connectivity options
Slower processors and less memory
No operating system features
Additional OS features like GPS and gyroscopes, enabling new app types

question: The OS provides a uniform, logical view of information storage by abstracting physical properties into a:
choices: File
Process
System call
Cache

question: What is the difference between a program and a process?
choices: A program is active, while a process is passive
A program is passive, while a process is active
A program has a program counter, while a process does not
There is no difference; the terms are interchangeable

question: How does a user process transition from user mode to kernel mode?
choices: By directly setting the hardware mode bit to 'kernel'
Through a system call, which triggers a trap
By causing a hardware interrupt
The user process never runs in kernel mode

question: Which of the following is an activity of Mass-Storage Management?
choices: Providing mechanisms for process communication
Allocating and deallocating memory space as needed
Disk scheduling and free-space management
Creating and deleting files and directories

question: What is privilege escalation?
choices: The process of a user changing their password
An attack that defends the system against worms and viruses
The process of allowing a user to change to an effective ID with more rights
A mechanism for controlling access to resources defined by the OS

question: What is a VMM (Virtual Machine Manager)?
choices: The guest operating system running on a host
A set of software frameworks like databases and multimedia services
A program that provides virtualization services to create and run VMs
An application program running inside a virtual machine

question: Which technology is the logical base for cloud computing?
choices: Virtualization
Peer-to-peer networking
Multiprogramming
Asymmetric multiprocessing

question: In a multiprocessor environment, what is cache coherency?
choices: A situation where each CPU has a different version of the same data in its cache
A hardware-level mechanism to ensure all CPUs have the most recent value in their cache
A software protocol for managing cache replacement policies
The process of clearing all caches during a context switch

question: What is the purpose of dual-mode operation (user and kernel mode)?
choices: To allow the computer to run two different operating systems at once
To allow the OS to protect itself and other system components from user programs
To enable a single user to run two programs simultaneously
To distinguish between single-core and dual-core processors

question: A dual-core processor design involves:
choices: Two separate processor chips on the motherboard
Two CPU cores on a single chip
A chassis containing two separate computer systems
A CPU with two caches but only one execution core

question: What is the primary difference between protection and security?
choices: Protection controls access by processes/users, while security defends against internal/external attacks
Protection defends against external attacks, while security controls internal access
Protection involves user IDs, while security involves group IDs
There is no difference; the terms are synonymous in operating systems

question: Which of the following is an advantage of multiprocessor systems?
choices: Increased throughput and economy of scale
Improved reliability
Simple and advanced programming models
Slower performance than single-processor systems
